did.unittitle: Postcards
Postcards
Africa (local peoples) [John Hinde postcards]
Young Africa; Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

YOUNG AFRICA: The laughter of the African child is warm and infectious, displaying the gaiety and exuberance so characteristic of Africans. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Gathering Coconuts. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

PALM-FRINGED BEACHES, lapped by warm waters, deserted, and stretching mile after mile, constitute one of Africa's many tourist attractions. Photographed , Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Fruit stall; Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MOMBASA. The aroma and colour of a typical fruit stall, presenting a wide variety of tropical produce, enchants the passer-by. Printed and Published b John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
River Scene. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

RIVER SCENE: The African coast is broken by deltas and lagoons. In these calm waterways river people carry goods tor sale and barter. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
An African Village. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

AFRICAN VILLAGE HUTS, fashioned from mud and bark, huddle together in warm neighbourly clusters. The season's grain is kept in large earthen storehouses. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
El-Molo Fisherman.

EL MOLO FISHERMAN: One of the world's smallest tribes live on the shores of the 3,500 sq. miles alkaline Lake Rudolf. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Fisherman. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

FISHERMEN: Africa's waters abound with fish. Fishermen glide down lagoons and rivers, casting nets. Others brave boiling surf in homemade dug-outs. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Leather Worker. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

LEATHER WORKERS produce saddlery, wallets, bags and shoes. All the exquisite design and embroidery is done by men instead of women. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Market Women. Photo: E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios.

MARKET WOMEN chat with friends and haggle over prices with the buyer. Here one buys peppers, tomatoes, onions, as well as exotic fruits. Photographed, Published and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Famous handicraft chests, Zanzibar. Photo: E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios.
ZANZIBAR, famous for its cloves, is also famous for various handicrafts and in particular decorated chests. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Market. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

AFRICAN MARKET: Customers haggle over prices, chat amongst friends and it is here that all local foodstuffs change hands. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Market. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

AFRICAN MARKET: Customers haggle over prices, chat amongst friends and it is here that all local foodstuffs change hands. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Vasco da Gama Street, Mombasa, Kenya.
VASCO DAGAMA STREET is typical of the narrow streets in the old town and is a reminder of its stormy history. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Colourful tribesmen.

TRIBESMEN in colourful regalia, inhabiting the high ground above the Kavirondo Gulf of Lake Victoria as far as the foot of Mt. Elgon. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Deep-sea Angling.

DEEP-SEA ANGLING: African waters swarm with big-game fish such as blue or black marlin, sail -fish and hammerhead sharks. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Flame Tree. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

AFRICAN FLAME TREE (Sterculia Acerifolia). Known as the " flame of the forest" this tree is a riot of flamboyant red and emerald green. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Festival Dancers. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

DANCING: Harvest-time and religious festivals are occasions for dancing, when the swaying bodies of the men and women display the African's gift for rhythm. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Calabash Carver. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

CARVING decorative designs on sun-ripened gourds is a traditional craft. Originally used as containers, carved calabashes are now popular tourist souvenirs. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Milk-maids. Color Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MILK MAIDS: Women go to market with their calabashes of skim milk and there sell it to buy the needs of the family. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Masai homestead. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MASAI: The life of this pastoral nomadic tribe revolves around their cattle, off whose milk and blood they almost entirely live. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. dublin, republic of Ireland.
Chuka Drummers- Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

DANCING : Harvest-time and religious festivals are occasions for dancing, when the swaying bodies of the men and women display the African's gift for rhythm. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Mother and Child. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE AFRICAN CHILD begins life snuggled in the soft cradle of his mother's back, held by a cloth wrapped around her. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Country Girl. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

COUNTRY GIRL: Some young African girls use antimony mascara to enhance the eyes and for patterning the face and neck with stunning effect. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Brass Ware Vendor. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

BRASS WARE VENDOR: The African's skill in decorative design is seen in the brass bowls offered for sale by this young merchant. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
The Potter. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE POTTER: The art of pottery is carried on throughout Africa and fulfils the need of the African for water and beer pots. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Fruit Vendor. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

AFRICAN MERCHANTS: African people are natural-born traders. Women operate in local markets and all carry loads of saleable items on their heads. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Pounding Grain. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

POUNDING GRAIN: For centuries African women have pounded their millet, corn, or cassava roots as the first step in preparing the family meal. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Market. Photo: E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios

MARKET WOMEN chat with friends and haggle over prices with the buyer. Here one buys peppers, tomatoes, onions. as well as exotic fruits. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Town Girl. Photo : E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios.

TOWN GIRL: This young lady has cheerfully discarded the traditional dress of her sisters elsewhere in Africa and dashingly flaunts western-style clothes. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Masai woman. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MASAI WOMAN: A pastoral nomadic tribe. The women shave their heads and are adorned by enormous beaded ear and neck ornaments. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Smiling Girl. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

AFRICAN WOMEN: Facial markings are a common feature among the women of Africa. From childhood they skilfully carry heavy loads on their heads. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
High Fashion. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

HIGH FASHION: African women wear innumerable hair styles. Usually the hair is greased, combed, tightly braided and then decorated, sometimes with beads or shells. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Masai Woman.

MASAI WOMAN : A pastoral nomadic tribe. The women shave their heads and are adorned by enormous beaded ear and neck ornaments. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Turkana tribesman.

TURKANA TRIBE of North-West Kenya are cattle people and strong individualists. The men have very elaborate hair styles which are regularly reset. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Chuka Drummer. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

DANCING: Harvest-time and religious festivals are occasions for dancing, when the swaying bodies of the men and women display the African's gift for rhythm. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Turkana Woman.

TURKANA of Northwest Kenya: the women of Turkana society have a high status and dress in superb bead and shell ornaments. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Abaluhya tribesman

ABALUHYA TRIBE is the collective name given to the large group of Bantu-speaking people living above the Kavirondo Gulf of Lake Victoria. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Masai herdboy and his dog. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MASAI: The life of this pastoral nomadic tribe revolves around their cattle, off whose milk and blood they almost entirely live. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Masai Elder. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MASAI : The life of this pastoral nomadic tribe revolves around their cattle, off whose milk and blood they almost entirely live. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Masai woman. Colour Photo byJohn Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MASAI WOMAN: A pastoral nomadic tribe. The women shave their heads and are adorned by enormous beaded ear and neck ornaments. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Ebony Carver. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

WOOD-CARVING illustrates in profusion and detail the life of the African people. Skilled craftsmen with crude tools attain remarkably fine finishes. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Warrior. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.S.P.

AFRICA'S WARRIORS are fearless fighters and hunters. Tribesmen have to prove their courage and strength before being given the responsibilities of manhood. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Fisherman. Photo : E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios.

FISHERMEN glide silently over the water, one man poling while the other casts his hawk-net to draw in the catch. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Sheltered Bay. Photo : E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios.

AFRICA'S COASTLINE offers an endless variety of wonderful beaches, with here and there a sheltered cove or mile upon mile of deserted beaches. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Africa (tourists) [John Hinde postcards]
Ngorongoro Crater, Tanzania. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

NGORONGORO CRATER has been described as the "Garden of Eden" . lts 102 sq. miles floor is the home of thousands of wild animals. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Palm-fringed Beach. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

PALM-FRINGED BEACHES, lapped by warm waters, deserted, and stretching mile after mile, constitute one of Africa's many tourist attractions. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Photographic Safari, East Africa. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

EAST AFRICA, with its vast game lands, provides amateur and professional photographers alike with exciting subject material demanding skill and patience. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Africa (buildings) [John Hinde postcards]
Dar es Salaam Harbour, Tanzania. Colour Photo by john Hinde, F.R.P.S.

DARES SALAAM, the ''haven of peace", is the seaside capital and principal port of Tanzania with a population of approximately 250,000. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lutheran Church, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Colour Photo by john Hinde, F.R.P.S.
THE LUTHERAN CHURCH, completed in 1907, is one of the landmarks along the beautiful Dar es Salaam seafront. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
The Kilimanjaro Hotel, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE KILIMANJARO is one of East Africa's most luxurious hotels. This spacious ten-storey building with 200 beds offers comfort in delightful surroundings. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Hindu Temple, Mombasa, Kenya.
THIS HINDU TEMPLE is comparatively new and renowned for its brilliantly painted doors. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Norfolk Hotel, Nairobi, Kenva. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

NORFOLK HOTEL, of international standard, is within five minutes walk of the city centre, offering excellent cuisine, leisurely atmosphere and a swimming pool. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Kenyatta Avenue, Nairobi. Photo : E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios.

NAIROBI, Kenya's sunny capital, is the only modern city in within the lion's roar and the starting point for adventure in East Africa. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Parliament Buildings, Nairobi, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

PARLIAMENT BUILDINGS : Dominated by a striking clock tower, these buildings are one of the city's best examples of modern architecture. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Oceanic Hotel, Mombasa, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

OCEANIC HOTEL, of international standard, has air-conditioned dining room and cocktail bar and a swimming pool. It is situated 1 mile from the town centre. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Hotel Ambassadeur, Nairobi, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hinde F.R.P.S.

HOTEL AMBASSADEUR, one of East Africa 's leading luxury hotels of international standard, is specially noted for its courteous and efficient personal service. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
New Stanley Hilton Hotel, Nairobi, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F. R.P.S.

NEW STANLEY HILTON HOTEL, of international standard, is situated in the centre of Nairobi offering most comfortable accommodation and excellent cuisine. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Panafric Hotel, Nairobi, Kenya. ColourPhoto by John Hilde F.R.P.S.

PANAFRIC HOTEL offers first class accommodation and facilities of international standard with superb cuisine and service, together with a new luxury swimming pool. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Vasco da Gama Memorial, Malindi, Kenya.

MALINDI was subjugated by the Portuguese in the 16th and 17th centuries and they established their headquarters here. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Africa (seascapes and landscapes) [John Hinde postcards]
Mount Kilimanjaro. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MOUNT KILIMANJARO (19,340 feet) Africa's highest mountain, permanently snowcapped. An extinct volcano offering a challenge to the climber. Usually cloud free in January. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Ngorongoro Crater, Tanzania. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

NGORONGORO CRATER has been described as the " Garden of Eden". Its 102 sq. miles floor is the home of thousands of wild animals. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Nyali Floating Bridge, Mombasa, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

NYALI FLOATING BRIDGE links the island to the north side of the mainland where popular resorts provide good hotels and splendid beaches. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic.
Likoni Ferry, Mombasa, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

LIKONI FERRY links the southern mainland with the colourful tiny island, redolent with stormy history and traditionally called the "Island of War". Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co,. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Dar es Salaam Harbour, Tanzania. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

DAR ES SALAAM HARBOUR, with deep-water berths, a bulk oil jetty and extensive facilities, handles over 1,200,000 tons of cargo annually. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabiteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland
Dar es Salaam Harbour, Tanzania. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

DAR ES SALAAM HARBOUR showing the departure of a large seagoing vessel and the ferry which links the city with Kigamboni. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limted, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
The beach, Malindi, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

MALINDI, the holidaymaker's paradise on East Africa's coast, is a wonderland for the skilled scuba diver and all water sports. Rinted and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Silversands Holiday Camp, Malindi, Kenya . Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

SILVERSANDS HOLIDAY CAMP is situated on Kenya's 300 mile Indian Ocean coast with warm crystal clear water and unspoilt palm-fringed beaches. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabonteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Fort Jesus, Kenya. Colour Photo by John Hindi, F.R.P.S.
FORT JESUS, built by the Portuguese at the end of the 16th Century, is now a museum housing relics of the past. Printed and Published by Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Africa (birds) [John Hinde postcards]
Speke's Weavers. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

SPEKE'S WEAVERS (Pioceus spekei) are among the world's best nest builders and their ball-like nests are ingeniously made of woven grass. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, CO. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Greater Flamingo and chick.

GREATER FLAMINGO (Phoenicopterus ruber roseus). Breed in large colonies building a rough mud nest 12" high on which they lay one egg. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely, Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
White-backed Vultures and Jackal. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

WHITE-BACKED VULTURE (Pseudogyps africanus). After a 'kill' vultures gorge themselves. Other scavengers like the Black-backed Jackal (Canis mesomelas) join in. Photographed, Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland
Greater Flamingoes. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

GREATER FLAMINGOES (Phoenicopterus ruber). Feed on alkaline lakes. Bills are specially adapted to extract minute organisms from the water, the bill is held upside-down when feeding. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Greater Flamingoes and Pelicans. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

GREATER FLAMINGOES (Phoenicopterus ruber). Feed on alkaline lakes. Bills are specially adapted to extract minute organisms from the water, the bill is held upside-down when feeding. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Greater Flamingoes. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

GREATER FLAMINGOES (Phoenicopterus ruber). Feed on alkaline lakes. Bills are specially adapted to extract minute organisms from the water, the bill is held upside-down when feeding. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Greater Flamingoes. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

GREATER FLAMINGOES (Phoenicopterus ruber). Feed on alkaline lakes. Bills are specially adapted to extract minute organisms from the water, the bill is held upside-down when feeding. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
East African Crowned Crane.

EAST AFRICAN CROWNED CRANE (Balearica pavonia). Feeds on insects and grain. They breed in marshy areas laying two or three eggs. Photographed, Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland
Vulturine Guinea-fowl.

VULTURINE GUINEA-FOWL (Acryllium vulturinum). The largest and most attractive of the seven species of Guinea-fowl to be found in Africa. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Butterfly.
A female Precis octavia Cramer, dry season form sesamus Trimen; this butterfly is a member of the Nymphalidae. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland
Africa (animals) [John Hinde postcards]
African Crocodile. Photo: E. Ludwig, John Hinde Studios

AFRICAN CROCODILE (Crocodylus niloticus). These huge reptiles spend the day basking on river banks, entering the water in the evening to hunt. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland
Grant's Zebra.

GRANT'S ZEBRA (Equus burchelli boehmi). There are several species distinguished by size and markings; while still abundant, some species have become extinct. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland
Antelope.

ANTELOPE : As the hot African sun lowers in the evening, many Antelope may be seen grazing on the Savannah Plains. Printed, and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland
Baby Thomson's Gazelle.

THOMSON'S GAZELLE (Gazelle Thomsonii). Better known as 'Tommies' and found only in East Africa; this youngster has not yet grown his horns. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Cape Buffalo and Egyptian Geese.

CAPE BUFFALO (Syncerus Caffer). Old bulls are often seen near water and care must be taken in approaching these dangerous animals. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Warthog.

WARTHOG (Phacochoerus aethiopicus). Despite their ferocious appearance, they are seldom aggressive; the tusks are used more for digging roots and tubers. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Topi. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE TOPI (Damaliscus korrigum jimela). A variety of antelope found in open parkland country. Distinguished by the angular curved horns. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Cheetah. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE CHEETAH (Acinonyx jubatus). The world's fastest animal-unlike the leopard they cannot climb. Young animals can be tamed and trained to hunt. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Leopard. Color Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE LEOPARD (Felis pardus). A powerful and agile animal. Having killed an antelope will often carry the carcase into a high tree. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Cheetah.

CHEETAH (Acinonyx Jubatus). The world's fastest animal for short distances, they can reach 60 m.p.h. The Antelope had no chance from this family. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Leopard.

THE LEOPARD (Felis pardus). A powerful and agile animal. Having killed an antelope will often carry the carcase into a high tree. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Cheetah. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE CHEETAH (Acinonyx jubatus). Considered the world's fastest animal, the legs have dog-like paws with non-retractile claws. Runs down its prey. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Elephant. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE ELEPHANT (Elephas africanus). A large bull may weigh 3-5 tons and the ivory tusks, which are enlarged incisors, may weigh 200 lbs. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Elephant and Marabous. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE ELEPHANT (Elephas africanus). A large bull may weigh 3-5 tons and the ivory tusks, which are enlarged incisors, may weigh 200 lbs. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Elephant. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE ELEPHANT (Elephas africanus). The most impressive of African animals. A large bull weighs 3-5 tons. The life span is about 50 years. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Elephant and calf. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

AFRICAN ELEPHANT (Elephas africanus). Young are born after a gestation period of 22 months and suckled for 3 years. Mature at 14 years. Photographed, Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Elephant Herd.

THE ELEPHANT. (Loxodonata africanus). The most impressive of African animals. A large bull weighs 3-5 tons. The life span is about 50 years. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
African Elephant and calf.

AFRICAN ELEPHANT. (Loxodonata africanus) . Young are born after a gestation period of 22 months and suckled for 3 years. Mature at 14 years. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lioness with cubs.

LIONESS (Panthera Leo) in the shade with her family of 3 month old cubs, who will remain with her until fully grown. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lions and Lioness. Colour Pholo by john Hinde, F.R.P.S.

THE LION (Felis leo). Large males are 3' 6" high with an overall length of nearly 10' and weighing 450 lbs. Females are smaller. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lioness. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

LIONESS (Panthera Leo) relaxing in the heat of the sun. These animals usually hunt early morning or in the evening Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lion Cub.
LION CUB: A month old lion cub waiting patiently in the shade for its mother to return from a hunting trip. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lioness
LIONESS (Panthera Leo) satisfies her thirst from a water hole during the heat of the day. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lioness and cub.
LIONESS (Panthera Leo). A 3 month old cub nestles near its mother who rests in the heat of the African sun. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Lion and Lioness. Colour Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

Hippopotamus.

HIPPOPOTAMUS (Hippopotamus amphibius) and EGYPTIAN GEESE (Alopochen aegyptiacus). The former is found on almost every river or lake in Africa. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Wildebeest.

WILDEBEEST (Connochaetes taurinus). Vast herds of these animals may be found in many parts of Africa, often mingling with Zebra. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Caracal.

CARACAL (Lynx caracal). An unusual photograph of a mother feeding her cubs. These cats, although small, are powerful animals and can even hunt down gazelle. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Giraffe.

THE GIRAFFE (Giraffa camelopardalis). Height up to 19'. Weight over 1 ton. Feeds on Acacia trees, stripping the leaves with its tongue. Printed and Published by John Hinde Limited, Cabinteely Co. Dublin, Republic of Ireland.
Grant's Zebra.

Spotted Hyena.

Bruxelles- Palais de Justice. Oevre de l'architecture Paelaert. Un des plus grands monuments du monde. Sa superficie est de 24,000 metres carres, s'eleve sur un soubassement rectangulaire de 180 metres de long et 170 de large, le Dome est fe 122 metres au-dessus du pave de la Rue, la Salre de Pas-Perdus a une hauteur de 97 metres; il possede 27 grandes salles, 245 pieces diverses et 8 cours, Inaugure en 1883. Sa construction dura 17 ans. (F. W. reproduction interdite.) [View of law courts of Brussels] [Work of architecture by [Phillip]Poelaert. One of the greatest monuments in the world. Its area is 24,000 square meters, rises on a rectangular base 180 meters long and 170 wide, the Dome is 122 meters above the street, the concourse has a height of 97 meters. It has 27 large rooms, 245 rooms and 8 different courses. Inaugurated in 1883. Its construction lasted 17 years. (F. W. reproduction prohibited.)

The House of Parliament, London.
LONDON. THE HOUSE OF PARLIAMENT. -The building was commenced in 1841, the architect being Sir Charles Barry. The Victoria Tower, at the extreme right of the picture is 346 feet high.
Peter Pan Statue, Kensington Gardens, London.
LONDON. PETER PAN STATUE. -Presented by Sir James Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan, and erected near the Serpentine.
St. Paul's Cathedral, London.
LONDON. ST. PAUL'S CATHEDRAL. -Occupies the ste of a former Gothic church. The first stone was laid in 1675, and the architect was Sir Christopher Wren.
The Cenotaph, White Hall, London.
LONDON. THE CENOTAPH. -Erected to the memory of "The Glorious Dead," and unveiled by King George on November 11th. 1920.
The Chames Embarkment, London.
LONDON. THE THAMES EMBARKMENT. -London's most maginificent public promenade. -The view shows thhe Hotel Cecil and Savoy Hotel, whilst in the foreground is Cleopratra's Needle.
London Bridge, London.
LONDON. LONDON BRIDGE. -The present bridge was commenced in 1824. The first London Bridge is said to have been built in 994.
Bukingham Palace, London.
LONDON. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. -The residence of His Majesty. The Palace is at the western end of the Mall.
The British Museum, London.
LONDON. THE BRITISH MUSEUM. -The National Treasure House contains valuable collection of Books, Manuscripts, and Sculpture.
The Queen Victoria Memorial, London.

LONDON. THE QUEEN VICTORIA MEMORIAL. -The Memorial was unveiled on May 16th, 1911, by King George V. in the presence of Queen Mary. The Memorial was designed and executed by Sir Thomas Brock, R.A. Upwaard of 2,000 tons of marble of the finest quality have been incorporated in the work, while some 800 tons of the finest Aberdeen granite were needed for the steps and pavement.
Westminster Abbey, London.

LONDON. WESTMINSTER ABBEY. -The earliest beginings of this beautiful Abbey are lost in legend, but Edward the Confessor's building was completed A.D. 1065, Henry III commenced the present building A.D. 1245.
The Mansion House, London.
LONDON. THE MANSION HOUSE. -The official residence of the Lord Mayor of London. The present building was erected in 1739.
The Strand, London.
LONDON. THE STRAND. -Probably the moost famous of London's busy thoroughfares.
Trafalgar Square, London.
LONDON. TRAFALGAR SQUARE. -The National Gallery is in Trafalgar Square. The Nelson Monument is on the right of the picture.
The Horse Guards, Whitehall, London.
LONDON. THE HORSE GUARDS. -Upon either side of the gateway sits a mounted sentry. They are probably the most stared-at-men in London.
The Grave of the Unknown Warrior, Westminster Abbey, London.
LONDON. THE UNKNOWN WARRIOR was buried on Nov. 11th, 1920, the Anniversary of Armistice Day.
The Roman Catholic Cathedral, London.
LONDON. THE ROMAN CATHOLIC CATHEDRAL. -The foundation-stone of this magnificent building was laid in 1895, and the Cathedral was opened in 1903. It is situated near Victoria Stret, Westminister.
The Royal Exchange and Bank of England, London.

LONDON. THE ROYAL EXCHANGE AND BANK OF ENGLAND. -The Royal Exchange ws erected in 1844, and is the third Exchange on the present site. The first was destroyed by the Great Fire, and was succeeded by another, which in turn was burnt down in 1838. The foundation-stone of the Bank of England was laid in 1732.
Aldwych, London.
LONDON. ALDWYCH. -This handsome new thouroughfare connects the Strand with High Holborn. Its construction necessitated the demolition of part of the historic Seven Dials.
Regent Street, London.
LONDON. REGENT STREET.- This famous street of beautiful shops commences at Pall Mall, and runs northwards through Piccadilly Circus and Oxford Circus.
Oxford Street, London.
LONDON. OXFORD STREET. -The heart of London shopping.
The Marble Arch, London.
LONDON. THE MARBLE ARCH. -The main north-west entry into Hyde Park. Park Lane, Bayswater Road, and Oxford Street meet here.
Triumphal Arch, Constitution Hill, London.
LONDON. THE DECIMUS BURION ARCH, at the top of Constitution Hill, surmointed by a quadriga, by Captain Adrian Jones, depicting Peace with Victory.
The Tower Bridge, London.

LONDON. THE TOWER BRIDGE. -The foundation-stone was laid by His late Majesty Edward VII, then Prince of Wales, in 1886, The centre span consists of two bascules, which are raised to allow the passage of large steamers, as seen in the picture.
The Tower of London.
LONDON. THE TOWER OF LONDON. -The Tower is of great historic interest, and contains the Crown Jewels, as well as a wonderful collection of armour of all periods.

Florence, Italy
Firenze-Il Fiume Arno e Ponte S. Trinita [Florence-The Arno River and the Holy Trinity Bridge]

Florence was originally situated on the right bank of the Arno only, but it extended at an early period in the middle ages to the opposite bank. The Ponte Sta. Trinita was erected in 1252 and rebuilt in 1567 by Bartolomeo Ammanati, restored and widened in 1867. It is adorned with allegorical statues of the seasons.
Firenze dalla via Barbacana [Florence seen from Via Barbacane]

Florence seen from Via Barbacan. Who can describe the charm of this pearl of Tuscany, surrounded by beautiful gardens on lovely hills! From such an enchanting spot you may have a wonderful view all over the town, with its fine buildings and the river Arno, which you will never forget.
Firenze dal Giardino di Boboli [Florence from the Boboli Gardens]

The views of Florence from the Garden of Boboli are very enchanting. The towers and palaces, the dome and campanile of the Cathedral, form a charming picture and the long walks borderned with evergreens, adorned with statues, attract crowds of pleasure-seekers on Sundays.

FIRENZE. Ponte Vecchio

Florence. Ponte Vecchio. The Ponte Vecchio, or Old Bridge, is said to have existed as early as the Roman period, and was finally rebuilt, after its repeated demolition, by Taddeo Gaddi in 1345. It consists of three arches, over which a covered passage is carried. Its sides are lined with goldsmiths' shops, which have stood there for centuries.
FIRENZE. Piazza dell'Annunziata e Ospedale degl'Innocent. [Annunziata Square and the Foundling Hospital]

Piazza dell'Annunziata. At the left corner of this picturesque square is the Palazzo Riccardi-Mannelli, a brick ediface with ornamentation in stone, erected by Buontalenti in 1565. The square is embellished with two baroque fountains; in the background is the Spedale degli Innocenti or Foundinling Hospital.
Roma, L'Aurora [The Aurora], Guido Reni.
Verso: [back of postcard]
[Florence]

Florence (Italian "Firenze") was formerly the capital of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany; from 1865 to 1870 it was the capital of the kingdom of Italy, and it ranks with Rome, Naples and Venice as one of the most attractive towns in Italy. In the middle ages the fine arts attained here the zenith of their glory, and still to-day an amazing profusion of treasures of art, as well as the delightful environs, render it one of the most beautiful cities in the world.

General Geo. A Custer; Curley, one of Custer's Trusted Crow Indian scouts. Custer's tragic battlefield where on June 25th, 1876 the gallant Major General and his little band of men were overwhelmed and killed by warriors of the Sioux and Cheyenne tribes - Near Crow Agency Monanta on the Burlington Line via Yellowstone and Glacier National Parks to the Pacific Northwest.

[Yosemite Falls, California]

Verso: YOSEMITE FALLS YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, CALIFORNIA. Nowhere else in the world may be seen a waterfall spectacle such as is found in Yosemite National Park. The Upper Yosemite Fall drops 1,430 feet in one sheer fall, a height equal to about nine Niagara Falls. The lower Yosemite Fall, immediately below, has a drop of 320 feet, or two Niagaras more. Counting the series of cascades in between, the total drop from the crest of the upper fall to the base of the lower fall is 2,425 feet.

United States of America (New Mexico)
Oldest house in the U.S.

Verso: Oldest house in the U.S., Santa Fe, New Mexico. The site of the Santa Fe (City of Holy Faith) was originally and Indian Pueblo. Onate had established his first capital at San Gabriel in 1598; in 1605 this was moved to the present site of Santa Fe, at which place a small Spanish village existed. This old house was one of the early structures of that time.
Kiva of ancient cliff dwellers, in ceremonial cave, Rito de los Frijoles Canyon, New Mexico

Verso: The Kiva or Estufa is a circular underground chamber from ten to forty odd feet in diameter, roofed with large vigas or timbers and covered with saplings and earth. Entrance is gained thru the hatch in the roof by means of a long ladder. An altar, fireplace, sipapu, flue or draft and various niches are essential features of the interior arrangement. The kiva is the ceremonial center of all Indian life and in this underground chamber, all important councils are held, and ceremonies and dances begin and end.

United States Capitol, Washington D.C.

Verso: The U.S. Capitol at Washington, D.C., was begin in 1793, the cornerstone of which was laid by Geroge Washington. The central building was finished in 1800, one wing in 1811, and was burned by the British in 1814. It ranks today among the noblest architectural objects in the world, its crowning glory being the Statue of Freedom which surmounts its dome 307 feet above the esplanade. At one end of the U.S. Senate, at the other the U.S. House of Representatives, the combined duties of whose members represent the greatest governmental undertaking in the world. It is 751 feet in length and 350 feet in width and covers an area of three and one-half acres. On its east central portico the oath of office is administered to each succeeding President by the Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court before a multitude of spectators.

Our Christian Era. This Painting by F. Luis Mora, on display at the DUN & BRADSTREET, INC. exhibit at the New York World's Fair, is eight feet in height by six feet in breadth. F. Luis Mora, N.A., was born in south America, the son of Domingo Mora, a distinguished Spanish sculptor. The murals, portraits, and water colors of F. Luis Mora appear in many public buildings, museums, and art galleries throughout the United States.

Verso: Our Christian Era. Christianity is the invinceable bulwark against fear, hatred, avarice, politics, purpose, cruelty in peace, selfishness, misunderstanding. Line after line of marchers, down, down, our Christian calendar; panoplied youth in armor, here and there a sword hilt graved by a heart that loved beauty, beauty used for the kill, chasulbles of broidered gold with jewels, candelabra of gold, candles for prayers and everywhere the symbol of the Cross. Armies of thousands upon thousands, marching, marching, marching. Drums, bugles and more drums. Yes! And flags, flags everywhere. Shining bayonets guilded by the sunset. Prayers for victory in the murderous battlefield and bombing the houses of God. Bodies frozen in moats of the dark ages and in the shell holes of today. On the mount sits that tired, saddened, lonely figure, still compassionate, stil asking, "Forgive them for they know not what they do." (The above wording appears in the panel of the painting)

Out Where the West Begins -Arthur Chapman [Poem]

"Out Where the West Begins" is a poem famous around the world as defining the spirit of West more effectively than anything written. It was written by Arthur Chapman, then a reporter on a Denver newspaper, on the occasion of a dispute as to the real boundary of the West. The poem and Mt. Holly Cross are two symbols of the marvelous West that are familiar to all.
